persons.name: Hippocrates
persons.description: Green physician of the classical period.

persons.name: Democritus
persons.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

persons.name: Miltiades
persons.description: Greek Athenian citizen known mostly for his role in the Battle of Marathon.

persons.name: Homer
persons.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

persons.name: Aristides
persons.description: An Athenian statesman remembered for his generalship in the Persian War.

persons.name: Leonidas
persons.description: King of the Greek city-state of Sparta.

places.name: Iran
places.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

persons.name: Alexander III
persons.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Xenophon
persons.description: A Greek military leader, historian and philosopher, who was a student of Socrates. He recorded some of Socrates' philosophy. He is mainly remembered for his book Anabasis.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Atheneus
persons.description: Of Naucratis was a Greek rhetorician and grammarian.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

persons.name: Almanon
persons.description: The Anglicised form of Al-Ma'mun, the seventh Abbasid caliph who reigned from 813-833 CE - a patron of learning.

places.name: Baghdad
places.description: the capital of Iraq and the second-largest city in the Arab world after Cairo

persons.name: Muhammad
persons.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.
